title: Ozone bleaching of jute fabrics

title: An Approach to Mass Customization of Military Uniforms Using Superoleophobic Nonwoven Fabrics (Postprint)
authors: Dnyanada Satam; Hoon Joo Lee; Eugene Wilusz
abstract: Abstract : This paper examines the design of modern military uniforms with emphasis on protection against hazardous chemicals. Design of military uniforms is governed by protective functions, quality, and economic feasibility. Along with protection, key performance features include high strength, light weight, moisture management, and comfort. The surface of hydroentangled nonwovens and nylon-cotton blended woven fabrics were modified, and made superhydrophobic and superoleophobic to protect soldiers against the threat of hazardous chemical and biological agents. Scenarios for the use of nonwoven fabrics and computer-aided design in the mass production and customization of military uniforms are proposed.

title: Soft-structured sensors and connectors by Inkjet Printing
authors: Amit Sawhney; Animesh Agrawal; Te-Chen Lo; Prabir Patra; Chi H. Chen; Paul Calvert
abstract: The properties of conducting polymers deposited onto textiles were studied over 10 years ago by workers at Los Alamos and Milliken who also tested these materials as gas sensors [1-3]. More recently, workers at Wollongong have demonstrated that elastic textiles impregnated with conducting polymers, by in situ chemical polymerization, can act as strain sensors that can be used to track the motion of human joints [4]. A similar approach can be used to make pressure-sensing foams [5]. Others have studied the strain sensing mechanism in more detail and have shown that two effects are important. In one case, cracking of the surface layer on conducting polymer on a fabric leads to a reduction in conductivity as the fabric is stretched [6, 7] . On the other hand, tests on yarns and loops of conducting yarn show that conduction from yarn to yarn decreases as stress is applied to pull their surfaces into contact [8].

title: Cyanuric Chloride Derivatives for Cotton Textile Treatment—Synthesis, Analysis, and Flammability Testing
authors: Michael W. Easson; Brian Condon; Megumi Yoshioka-Tarver; Stephanie Childress; Ryan Slopek; John M. Bland; Thach‐Mien Nguyen; SeChin Chang; Elena Graves
abstract: Two cyanuric chloride derivatives were synthesized in good yields and analyzed by proton, carbon, and phosphorus nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy as well as high performance liquid and gas chromatography mass spectrometry. Treated cotton fabric was tested for flame retardant properties using standardized thermogravimetric, limiting oxygen index, and vertical flame methods. Scanning electron microscopy images revealed the level of flame retardant protection. The results are reported herein and indicate cyanuric chloride derivatives have a potential use in flame retardant applications to cotton textiles.

title: Textile Industry 5.0? Fiber Computing Coming Soon to a Fabric Near You
abstract: As an industry, we've barely gotten our feet wet with Textile Industry 4.0, and now Textile Industry 5.0 is on the horizon! According to experts at Advanced Functional Fabrics of America (AFFOA), the development of functional fiber computing solutions will likely be the basis for moving us into Textile Industry 5.0.

title: Physical and Mechanical Properties of Chiengora Fibers
authors: Sandra C. Greer; P. Banks-Lee; Morgan Jones
abstract: Natural protein fibers, such as wool, mohair, and siik, currentiy used in textiie production can be very costiy, Altliough non-traditionai, a protein fiber, such as chiengora (dog hair), can prove to be a cheaper, environmentaiiy friendiy, and suitabie substitute. However, very iittie information on the properties of these fibers can be found in the iiterature. Here, the physicai and mechanical properties of hair combed from 18 dog breeds were measured and compared to those of traditionai animai hair fibers. Unwashed dog hair was coiiected, bagged and iabeied by professionai pet groomers. Resuits show that iength, iinear density, tenacity, strain, and elastic moduius of chiengora fibers are all simiiar to those of traditionai protein fibers. Results also show that hairs from some breeds may be suitabie for short- or long-staple processing.

Progress on enzymatic preparation of flax and flax wool blends
authors: Jinsong Shen; Sara M. Sampaio; David Bishop; A. Miettinen – Oinonen; Tzanko Tzanov
abstract: This paper is outcome from a European Commission funded project under the FAIR programme and under COST ACTION 847 “Textile Quality and Biotechnology”. It demonstrated the high level of international collaboration with VTT Biotechnology in Finland and Minho University in Portugal. The outcome of the paper brought in significant knowledge of traditional and novel enzymatic preparation for flax and flax blends to meet the cost effective production. The paper showed the leading research in the enzymatic treatment using laccases or laccases/mediator systems for degradation of lignin for producing high quality of flax textile materials. J Shen also published another two papers in the subject of evaluation of physical and chemical properties of flax fibres from stand-retted crops in JTI 2006 and Industrial Crops & Products 2005.

title: Soil Burial Effects on Biodegradation and Properties of Three Cellulosic Fabrics
authors: Mary Warnock; Kaaron Davis; Duane C. Wolf; Edward E. Gbur
abstract: Biodegradation rates of cellulosic fabrics in soil have forensic and environmental implications. Th e objective of this fi eld study was to determine the biodegradation rates of 100% rayon, cotton, and lyocell woven fabrics buried in a Captina silt loam soil. Following 14, 28, 42, 77, and 112 days of burial, the fabrics were excavated to determine the amount of fabric remaining and the performance properties of tensile and tearing strength plus fl ex abrasion. Biodegradation rates were described using zero-order kinetics. Warm, moist soil conditions resulted in half-life values (the time required for 50% of the fabric to decompose) of 22, 40, and 94 days of burial for rayon, cotton, and lyocell, respectively. Rapid degradation of experimental fabrics occurred under certain moisture and temperature conditions.

title: An assessment of the technical performance of photochromic dyes in textile printing
Changes in the non-cellulosic components of cotton surface after mercerization and scouring
authors: Igor Jordanov; Biljana Mangovska; Barbara Simončić; Petra Forte-Tavčer
abstract: M ercerization modifi es cotton structure and the cotton surface. Alkaline pectinase and acid pectinase scouring eliminates part of the cotton cuticle, allowing study of the intact and changed cuticle structure. Cuticle changes were analyzed through weight loss, CIE whiteness degree, CIELAB coordinates, water contact angle, surface free energy, XPS photoelectron spectroscopy, and dyeing the non-cellulosic components on the cotton surface. Th e best elimination of non-cellulosic components used alkaline scouring followed by alkaline pectinase and acid pectinase scouring of cotton yarns. Mercerization changes the cotton surface by removing part of the cuticle components, turning it into a continuous thin layer that is more easily removed by alkaline and alkaline pectinase scouring. Acid pectinase does not penetrate it, however, resulting in poor scouring effi ciency.

title: The evaluation of a natural pigment in cotton as a UV absorber
authors: Maria Gorenšek; Raša Urbas; Simona Strnad; Đurđica Parac-Osterman
abstract: The whiteness hue, and the higher UPF (ultraviolet factor) value of blank-bleached dyed cotton fabrics versus the UPF value of bleached dyed cotton fabrics, indicated the presence of a natural pigment in raw and blank-treated samples. Plain-woven, raw, lightweight cotton fabric was used. Desizing, blank bleaching, blank dyeing, and bleaching and dyeing processes were performed. CIE equations were used for determining sample whiteness and whiteness hue. Cover factor was calculated using the results of image analysis. Raw cotton fabric with the lowest cover factor had a 2.5x greater UPF value than bleached cotton fabric. The UPF value of bleached cotton fabric was cca. 3x lower than the UPF value of desized cotton fabric even through the two fabrics had almost the same cover factor.

title: Antibacterial and Physical Properties of Knitted Cotton Fabrics Treated with Antibacterial Finishes
authors: Mustafa Erdem Üreyen; Pelin Gürkan Ünal; Eylen Sema Namlıgöz; Diren Mecit Armakan; Aydın Doğan
abstract: The effects of commercial antibacterial finishing agent application on the physical properties of cotton fabrics, including laundering durability, were investigated. Applications were performed by the pad-dry-cure method. All fabric samples were washed 40 times. The physical properties (i.e., fabric weight, pilling, burst ing strength, air permeability, and color efficiency) and antibacterial activity of the treated and untreated fabrics were tested before washing and after every 10 laundering cycles. It was found that pilling, air perme ability, and bursting strength of the fabrics were affected significantly, but color efficiency was not affected by the antibacterial treatments. Good antibacterial activity could be achieved even after 40 launderings with many different antibacterial agents. However, the antibacterial activity of the samples treated with different agents varied.

title: The Smart Supply Chain: A Digital Revolution
Is Durability Sustainable?
abstract: Interestingly, the French word for sustainability is durabilité . And, of course, durability is at the heart of sustainability—isn't it? If a product is durable, it will last for a long time and this means that it won't be discarded quickly, which keeps it out of the land-fill longer. If it doesn't need to be replaced often, the product's total environmental impact is reduced across its lifecycle. On the other hand, if something is designed to last for a long time, does that mean that it won't break down for a long time after it has been discarded—and if so, how can that be viewed as sustainable? Take plastic bags, for example. In the case of a product that is designed to be thrown away after relatively few uses, biodegradability is better than durability. So maybe it all depends on context.

title: Ultrasonic energy in the textile industry
Colorfastness Properties of Dyed, Reduction Cleared, and Softened Poly(lactic acid) Fabrics
authors: Ozan Avinç; Mike Wilding; John Bone; Duncan Phillips; David Farrington
abstract: Soft eners are usually applied to fabrics, including those made from polylactic acid, to improve hand and to reduce friction between fi ber/fi ber and fi ber/metal during production. Commercially available soft eners of diff erent hydrophilicity, ionicity, and chemical type were applied to poly(lactic acid) fabric that was dyed to a heavy depth of shade with C.I. Disperse Blue 284 to evaluate the eff ect on wetfastness and lightfastness. Finishing with all soft eners reduced wetfastness but not lightfastness properties; little correlation was found with soft ener chemistry. In general, wetfastness and lightfastness of soft ened poly(lactic acid) fabrics were lower than that of soft ened poly(ethylene terephthalate) fabrics. Th e reduction in wetfastness, and particularly crockfastness, of poly(lactic acid) fabric was less marked if the soft ener was applied by an exhaustion process rather than by a padding process. Key Terms: Colorfastness, Finishing, PET, PLA, Poly(lactic acid), Soft ener

title: Antibacterial Properties of Citric Acid Used as Easy-Care Finishing Agent
authors: Sandra Bischof Vukušić; Sandra Flinčec Grgac; Drago Katović; Diana Brlek Gorski
abstract: The objective of this study is to evaluate the antibacterial properties of a cotton textile material treated with easy care finishing agent which additionally enhance antibacterial activity. Since it was noticed that some of the agents have negative influence on human health, an eco-friendly agent Citric acid (CA), was used in the study for the purpose of simultaneous easy-care and antimicrobial finishing. Until now, except for the easy-care, CA has been used as binder in flame retardant finishing of cellulose materials (textile, wood and paper) where it has shown excellent results. Determination of antibacterial activity of finished products was performed according to ISO 20743:2005 standard before and after the 5 washing processes. Antibacterial activity was tested against gram-positive (Staphylococcus aureus) and gram-negative (Escherichia coli) bacteria. Bactericidal activity of cotton samples was additionally tested according to EN 1276:1997 under the dirty conditions, according to its practical applications. Antibacterial activity of cotton material treated with CA has shown to be in the same log range with quaternary ammonium (Quat) agent, currently on the market. Obtained results are confirming the possibility of eco-friendly CA application, for the purpose of antimicrobial finishing.

title: ICP-OES Monitoring of Aluminum, Copper, Cobalt, Iron, and Manganese During Bleaching
abstract: The aim of this research work was to monitor aluminum, cobalt, copper, iron, and manganese during textile processing. Those particular metals were chosen because they can cause pin holing or cellulose degradation if present in higher amounts. The total amount of metals was determined by inductively coupled plasma – emission spectrometer after microwave digestion of materials with 7 M nitric acid. The results have shown that a possible cause of degradation of textile materials which occurres during bleaching treatment can be the presence of high concentrations of copper, which was found to be the dominant metal (8.1 -108.4 ppm), followed by iron (16.9 – 37.9 ppm). Cobalt, manganese and aluminum contents were under the detection limits (1.5, 0.1 and 28.3 ppb, respectively) for all samples tested.

title: Feasibility of Traceable Color Standards for Cotton Color
authors: James Rodgers; Jacqueline Campbell; Xiaoliang Cui; Devron P. Thibodeaux
abstract: Cotton color is measured on the Uster High Volume Instrument (HVI) for Rd (diffuse reflectance) and +b (yellowness): cotton-specific color parameters not as well known as other globally recognized color systems (e.g., CIELAB). Standards used for HVI color are ceramic tiles and cotton batts, but there is no National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIS1)-like traceability or means to verify/certify these standards. A comparative program investigated new standard procedures and protocols, evaluated globally recognized color systems, and developed traceable or verified/certified HVI color standards. Good to excellent color unit agreement was observed for the colortiles and Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) tiles when glass was not used in the measurement, but only fair agreement was observed for all units when glass was placed between the sample and the spectrophotometer port.

title: DP Finishing with Polycarboxylic Acids and Phosphono-Based Catalysts
authors: Sandra Bischof-Vukušić; Drago Katović; Ivo Soljačić
abstract: Polycarboxylic acid are gaining recognition as a new class of ecologicaly accepted formaldehyde free Durable Press (DP) agents. Since most of these reagents are much more expensive than N-methylol agents, which are still mostly used nowadays, they should impart extra end-use properties to justify high cost. Required quantities which are necessary for good easy care performance of cotton fabric are depending greatly on applied polycarboxylic acid (PCA). Finding an optimum catalyst system for PCA curing is still an open problem which must be solved. Best effects of esterification reaction followed by good strength retention and whiteness properties, have been obtained with sodium hypophosphyte (SHP), which is rather expensive as well. For the replacement of SHP, much cheaper catalysts based on the phosphonic acid, were tried to apply, alone or in different ratios with SHP. These catalysts were sodium salts of phosphonic acid in two different forms: tetrasodium salt of the hydroxyethylidene 1, 1-diphosphonic acid (HEDPA) and octasodium salt of the diethylenetriaminepentamethylenphosphonic acid (DETMPA). Addition of phosphono based catalysts as accelerators in a system with BTCA, CA and their mixture has enhanced their effectiveness as DP finishing agents in few cases. More significant is possible reduction of 50% SHP in CA treatment, and 30% in a case of BTCA treatment, while keeping good resiliency results.

title: Single-bath bleaching and fiber bundle size reduction of flax using ultrasound
authors: Maja Andrassy; Emira Pezelj; Ružica Čunko
abstract: The application of ultrasound in the bleaching bath was studied for improving the quality of flax fibers by fiber bundle size reduction in one step. Five flax cultivars provided the fiber samples used. Experiments were conducted at various temperatures and with and without ultrasound. Treatment efficiency was determined by measuring the loss of mass from the technical fiber, the degree of fiber bundle size reduction, and changes in color, lightness, and luster. Improvements were seen in most of these areas, with no effect on the whiteness degree and reduced bleaching effectiveness due to ultrasound treatment.

title: Care practices for fluorocarbon treated garments: A case study
authors: Elizabeth P. Easter; Bruce E. Ankenman
abstract: High performance textiles are no longer restricted to the industrial or institutional textile markets. The media is flooded with high-tech claims associated with consumer products, such as fabrics that eliminate odors, moisture management systems and thermal adaptive fabrics. For example, in the spring and summer of 2002, Savane®, Dockers®, Lee® Jeans and Haggar®, all leading manufacturers of men’s and women’s pants, offered products with stain repellent finishes. Ads on TV and the Internet promoted a new treatment on a khaki fabric that enables stains to just roll off the pants. Kristen Thomas, Vice President of Nano-Tex pours coffee, red wine and tea with milk on a pair of beige colored cotton pants... and the three solutions bead up on the garment’s surface and are wiped off with a quick brush of the hand.

title: Cationized Cotton: Opportunities and Challenges
Inside the Crystal Ball: A Look at the Textile Industry’s Evolving Future
Colors of the Future: Color Psychology and Textile Aesthetic
Investigation of the most effective cotton digestion procedure
abstract: Three digestion procedures have been tested for cotton digestion in order to determine major, minor and trace elements by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry. Homogenized samples were subjected to dry ashing, open-vessel digestion and microwave digestion and analyzed for presence of 28 elements. The best recoveries of all elements were detected after microwave digestion procedure. Dry ashing was the best method for determination of As, K, Mg, Mn and Na, while open-vessel digestion for Al, Be, Ca and Sb. For the determination of Cd and Co microwave digestion procedure achieved the highest recoveries. The accuracy of digestion methods was estimated by analysis of a certified reference material. Very good agreement within the certified and experimental values was found for the majority of the elements investigated.

title: Assessing structural changes in cotton yarns during wet processing, mercerization, and scouring
authors: Igor Jordanov; Biljana Mangovska; Petra Forte Tavčer
abstract: Key Terms: Cotton, Enzymatic Scouring, Mercerization, Pectinase, Scouring, Yarns Consumer demand for improved cotton quaJit)' is on the rise as they become more aware of its influence on the properties of knitted fabrics (i.e., cotton quality affects dimensional stabihty, pill formation, and abrasion resistance). Knitted fabrics are mainly produced from ringor OE-spun cotton yarns. Researchers have studied the structural, physical, and mechanical properties of ringand OE-spun yarns. OE-spun yarns are more even; bulkier; and have lower tensile strength, elongation, and hairiness, but greater friction and abrasion resistance than ring-spun yarns.'^' For ring-spun yarns, fibers around the yarn center are almost parallel to the yarn axes.'' The use of OE-spun yarns for knitted fabrics offers several advantages, such as large package size, uniform strength and evenness, low hairiness, smooth fabric appearance, and a lower propensity to p'lWJ Despite the attractive yarn properties, fabrics knitted from open-end spun yarns have a somewhat harsh felling, due to the presence of wrapper fibers and a higher level of twist, often do not exhibit good stitch clarity, and have greater relaxation. These problems can be solved by yarn or knitted fabric treatments. Enzymes have found a variety of uses in textile applications. They are biological catalysts usually derived from a fungal or bacterial source. Enzymes consist of complex, three-dimensional proteins composed of polypeptide chains. These enzymes promote the hydrolysis of specific substrates, converting water-insoluble materials to water-soluble products that can be washed away. Ceilulases are most frequently used to remove surface hairiness and neps, and to improve hand and flexibility. Research has been done on enzyme treatment of cotton yarns as well as of knitted cotton fabrics made from differently-spun yarns.'Another way of improving the quality of knitted-cotton fabrics is mercerizarion of the yarns or fabrics. Mercerization can give these yarns or fabrics better dimensional stability, increased luster, increased dye and finishing-chemicals uptake, and better mechanical properties and smoothness. Yarn mercerization is usually done on raw cotton yarns. After mercerization, the yarns are scoured, bleached, or dyed (usually as hanks) and knitted into various knitted structures. Cotton yarn scouring can be done by traditional alkali treatment or by alternative commercially-viable enzyme treatment. Different enzyme classes have been investigated for use in scouring, including pectinases, ceilulases. Upases, and proteases. The best results were obtained with pectinases—degradation of pectin by pectinase enzymes facilitated the removal of the cuticle components. ' ' ' Aikaiine pectinase and acid pectinase are commonly used. Various parameters, such as enzyme concentration, temperature, pH, and chelating agent concentration for alkaline pectinase and acid pectinase treatment were determined in previous work. ' ' In general, alkaline scouring could be replaced by enzymatic scouring. Knitted fabrics made of enzymatic-scoured yarns, as well as knirted fabrics which had been enzymaticaily-scoured, had better quality parameters than those that were alkaline scoured.'''' 56 AATCC Review AUGUST 2007

Sustainability, Slow Fashion, and the Circular Economy—is it the Next Great Opportunity?
Making Tough Choices
abstract: he international apparel business is owning up to its role as one of the planet's most polluting industries. We recognize that engaging in more sustainable practices will help curb climate change and will also have a positive effect on corporate image in the mind of today's consumers.Figuring out where to start on the sustainability spectrum, however, can be a daunting task. Many industry leaders will admit that we have a long way to go. Like any new initiative, course correction requires time, patience, and resources; and each which will vary depending on the size and age of your organization. It all boils down to making some tough choices.

title: Military Fabrics: A Matter of Life and Death
abstract: Military combat uniforms are primarily designed with the goal of increasing the combat effectiveness of the soldiers who wear them. Incorporating features such as camouflage patterns to make them less likely to be spotted in certain terrains, and flame-resistance to reduce their vulnerability to fire, military uniforms can literally be a matter of life and death. Today, technological advances have drastically increased the features that can be incorporated into the fabric of military outfits to give soldiers an even greater advantage.

Microcapsule Durability on Polymide-Knitted Fabrics Assessed by Streaming Potential Analysis
authors: Tanja Pušić; Irena Petrinić; Tanja Luxbacher; Ivo Soljačić
abstract: The study is focused on streaming potential analysis as a control method for microcapsule durability, during washing.. Various concentrations of skin-care microcapsules were applied on ladie's pantyhose made from a polyamide-elastane blend. Zeta potential of untreated and treated pantyhose was measured at variousof pH values in an electrolyte solution before and after 1 and 10 wash cycles. The effect of microencapsule tratment on the negative zeta potential at high pH correlated with the microcapsule concentration in the treatment bath. The pH dependence of zeta potential indicates microcapsules durability after the first wash cycle but suggests complete removal after 10 wash cycles.

title: Characterisation of N-Methylol dimethyl phosphonopropionamide (MDPA) and Citric Acid FR Bonding System
authors: Sandra Bischof Vukušić; Drago Katović; Sandra Flinčec Grgac
abstract: Performance of novel flame retardant (FR) system consisting of MDPA, citric acid and sodium hypophosphite catalyst (SHP) was evaluated on cotton fabric. To determine the bonding mechanism, MDPA concentration was increased from 0% to 48%, while citric acid (9%) and sodium hypophosphite (4.5%) concentrations were unchanged. Citric acid is known to esterify cotton cellulose and react with MDPA, thus increasing MDPA bonding to cotton. The number of linkages was determined by wrinkle recovery angle and infrared measurements. Results showed the linear increase of the limiting oxygen index (LOI) and, consequently, decrease of char length values cased by the phosphorus concentration increase in the applied system. For FR results durable to 10 wash cycles, 36% MDPA, 9% citric acid and 4.5% sodium hypophosphite was used.

title: How Fares Marx in the Twenty-First Century?
abstract: The article discusses the relevance of Marx in the present moment. The argument is that if we seek to use Marx for understanding contemporary capitalism it is necessary to approach his work in a non- orthodox manner.

title: Why Denim Never Fades
Going Forth and Coming Home: Hospitality and Home Fabrics Tackle Sustainability
The New Digital World: Color Management Challenges
The Science Behind Fabric Durability
The Important Role of the Designer
abstract: This was the sound advice given by British designer Vivienne Westwood, when she was asked in 2018 about ethical and environmental issues in the fashion industry. It remains equally valid in 2020 and will continue to be the ethical code by which we should shop in the future. People in the textile and apparel industry are well aware of their responsibility to create a more sustainable supply chain, to reduce waste in production processes, and to recycle materials whenever possible. And much of the responsibility for these activities starts with the design team—groups of unsung heroes who have to juggle budgets, logistics, strategic plans, technology, aesthetics, functionality, and so much more. Designing goods for sustainability can mean many things—including: • designing high quality, durable products; • designing products that can be disassembled easily at their end-of-life, so that the materials and components can be easily recycled; • designing products which are made from organic, biodegradable, reclaimed or recycled materials and components; • designing products which generate a minimal amount of waste and pollution during their manufacture; • designing products which can be manufactured using machinery that can run on renewable energy, and consume a minimal amount of water; and • choosing manufacturing locations and distribution methods to minimize carbon emissions.

title: Environmentally Healthy Ways to Keep Clothes out of the Washing Machine
abstract: There are many good reasons for reducing the amount of time your clothes spend in the washing machine. According to The Ellen MacArthur Foundation, synthetic fabrics shed plastic particles equivalent to 50 billion plastic bottles every year. But synthetic fibers are not the only culprit. Washing clothes— regardless of the fiber type, is a water and energy guzzling affair. Unfortunately, many people believe their clothes only have one or two wear cycles before they need to be laundered. However, there are some environmentally cost-effective ways that might convince people that clothes do not have to be washed so often.

title: Performance Apparel: Challenges & Innovations
abstract: Companies operating in the performance apparel sector tend to react quickly and innovatively to the challenges which they face. Innovation is the industry's response to a range of current challenges.<br/> Some of the current challenges include creating a more sustainable supply chain; reducing water pollution; applying the principles of a circular economy; traceability in the apparel supply chain; and streamlining logistics across geographical regions.

title: Fabrics for Dirty Jobs
Thinking Through the Post-Pandemic Supply Chain
A More Sustainable Textile Supply Chain
Digital Printing: Machine and Ink Innovations
Backing Up Marketing Buzzwords
abstract: Brands are built on the concept of recognition and differentiation in the marketplace. Today's branding is made to evoke a 'je ne sais quoi," sometimes aspirational, sometimes comforting, sometimes outright outlandish, but nonetheless recognizable and relatable. Product categories and trends come and go just like brands. However, some endure for decades with very simple common products or corner the market with complex signature ones. Others quickly become a distant memory in the minds eye of the consumer.
